author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Can a Neighborhood Be Instagrammed to Death?
description: The return of tourism to New York has brought crowds back to one of the most popular selfie spots on earth. People who live there aren’t feeling #grateful.
content: Two years ago, Prokopis Christou, a scholar of the social and psychological dynamics of tourism, published a paper that sought to determine whether people who took selfies at popular destinations tended to marginalize the destination itself, focusing instead almost entirely on their own image.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: A Nuclear U-Turn
description: Russian gas cuts force Germany to reconsider shutting its atomic power plants.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker and Niraj Chokshi
title: Amtrak Rewarded Executives With Six-Figure Bonuses as Rail Service Struggled
description: Most of the top leaders received bonuses above $200,000 in the last fiscal year, as Amtrak worked to recover from the coronavirus pandemic.
content: Amtrak’s top executives received six-figure incentive bonuses in 2021, their biggest payouts in years, despite the service’s lackluster financial performance and weak ridership caused by the pandemic, according to data obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: ‘Don’t Start Anything’
description: Scrolling through Instagram, a formerly ultra-Orthodox Jewish woman wonders what happened and what could have been.
content: I’ve read many Modern Love submissions about encountering old crushes and high school flames online. (First love never dies, right? Especially in the digital age.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: In a House Race With Big Names, 2 Women With Local Ties Rise
description: Carlina Rivera, a Manhattan councilwoman, and Yuh-Line Niou, a state assemblywoman, are vying to defeat rivals who include current and former members of Congress.
content: Two months ago, the megawatt contest for a rare open House seat in New York City seemed destined to be shaped by one of a handful of nationally known candidates.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Poems in Practice and in Theory
description: Elisa Gabbert talks about her poetry criticism and her own poems, and Ian Johnson discusses Wang Xiaobo’s novel “Golden Age.”
content: Elisa Gabbert, the Book Review's On Poetry columnist, visits the podcast this week to discuss writing about poetry and her own forthcoming collection of poems, her fourth, “Normal Distance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele and Vimal Patel
title: 10 Dead in Fast-Moving Pennsylvania Fire, Officials Say
description: Among those killed in the blaze, at a home in Nescopeck in the northeastern part of the state, were several relatives of a firefighter who was at the scene.
content: A fire described as “violent” and “forceful” swept through a home in Northeastern Pennsylvania early on Friday morning, killing 10 people, including several relatives of a firefighter who responded to the blaze, according to the authorities and the firefighter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: Prosecutor Who Investigated Police Corruption Will Lead N.Y.P.D. Watchdog
description: Charles M. Guria will become the next inspector general for the department under a mayor who has focused on the police.
content: A veteran city prosecutor who investigated police corruption over a three-decade career will become the next inspector general for the New York City Police Department, taking on a crucial oversight role under a mayor who has made aggressive policing a priority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
title: Fire at Thailand Nightclub Kills at Least 13
description: Witnesses said the flames spread rapidly. A video showed victims running from the building with their clothes ablaze.
content: BANGKOK — A fire broke out in a crowded music pub in Thailand’s eastern Chonburi Province early Friday morning and spread quickly, killing at least 13 people and injuring about three dozen, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Albert Woodfox, Survivor of 42 Years in Solitary Confinement, Dies at 75
description: His term in solitary was perhaps the longest in American history. He described how he kept his sanity, and dignity, in an acclaimed memoir.
content: Albert Woodfox, who spent 42 years in solitary confinement — possibly more time than any other prisoner in all of American history — yet emerged to win acclaim with a memoir that declared his spirit unbroken, died on Thursday in New Orleans. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: Apocalyptic photographers, amnesiac killers and dueling Karen Gillans make up this month’s sci-fi selections.
content: Just a few minutes into this new South Korean import, it’s obvious we are in for a completely bonkers ride. Shortly after waking up with amnesia and a cross-shaped incision on the back of his neck, Carter (Joo Won, the star of the original Korean version of “The Good Doctor”) has recovered enough to brutally dispatch dozens of half-naked foes in a blood-soaked melee inside a bath house. He hears a woman’s voice in his head that informs him that a spreading virus is turning people into bald zombielike maniacs, and he must deliver the antidote to North Korea. Should Carter, a rogue former C.I.A. operative, trust a disembodied voice from North Korea to begin with? You have one guess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Welcome to Soccer’s Strangest Season
description: The World Cup will split seasons in two in much of the world, including the Premier League campaign that opens this weekend. What is revealed could be fascinating.
content: Gian Piero Ventrone surveyed his handiwork with just the hint of a smile. A few minutes earlier, Ventrone, Tottenham Hotspur’s fitness coach, had gathered the club’s players together on the turf at the Seoul World Cup stadium and informed them of their next assignment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Keyshawn Johnson Wants the N.F.L. to Remember Its ‘Forgotten Four’
description: The former Pro Bowl receiver lobbied Pro Football’s Hall of Fame to honor Kenny Washington, Woody Strode, Bill Willis and Marion Motley, the four Black players who reintegrated the league in 1946.
content: Keyshawn Johnson’s history lesson began with a question. In 2020, Bob Glauber, a Newsday reporter, wanted to write a book about Kenny Washington and Woody Strode, whose signings to the Los Angeles Rams in 1946 broke an effective ban on Black players in the N.F.L.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corny on Main
description: Sometimes you just can’t get enough of those sweet, fresh summer cobs.
content: Last week, I told you I was in full tomato mode. Which is true. But it’s not the whole story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien, John Liu and Paul Mozur
title: Fight or Surrender: Taiwan’s Generational Divide on China’s Threats
description: In areas close to the military drills, younger Taiwanese worried about the future, while older residents looked back to a harsher past to find hope.
content: KINMEN COUNTY, Taiwan — The San Jiao Fort cafe on Kinmen Island may well be the best place in Taiwan to watch for the threat of invasion by China. Boasting a direct view of the Chinese city of Xiamen just six miles away, it is built atop an old military bunker, festooned with camouflage netting, and serves hot and cold beverages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: In Defense of Daydreaming
description: Letting your mind wander can benefit the brain, researchers say.
content: Whenever I have a few moments of down time — every weekday, for instance, when I’m waiting in the car pool pickup line for my children at camp — I grab my phone and check to see whether anything interesting has happened on Instagram. The thing is, I don’t particularly like Instagram. Social media usually makes me feel insecure, but somehow that is preferable to sitting alone with my thoughts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: How Arizona Became an Abyss of Election Conspiracy Theories
description: This week’s primaries showed how Donald Trump’s lies about the 2020 election have gripped Arizona Republicans. To learn why, we spoke with a reporter who has deeply covered the state.
content: Of the roughly three dozen states that have held primary elections this year, Arizona is where Donald Trump’s conspiratorial fantasies about the 2020 election seem to have gained the most purchase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Premier League Preview: Has Arsenal Pulled It Together? Will United Fall Apart?
description: Six contenders (more or less) and five story lines (plus a few extra) as the new season kicks off with everyone chasing Manchester City (again).
content: Somehow, it is that time again. Cue the dramatic music, crank up the content generator and get ready to absorb the hottest takes around: the Premier League season is upon us once again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Mydans
title: ‘Captain Condom’ Turned the Tide in Thailand’s War on AIDS and Overpopulation
description: At a time when most Thais avoided discussing safe sex and family planning, Mechai Viravaidya promoted condom use with spectacle and humor, saving millions of lives.
content: BANGKOK — Mechai Viravaidya twice saw Thailand in desperate trouble — first from a ruinous population explosion and then from the AIDS epidemic — and he responded to both crises the same way: with condoms and his own considerable charisma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: Slow-Cooked Lamb That Can Stand the Heat
description: A meaty main, cooked indoors or out, anchors David Tanis’s August menu, book-ended by a light tomato-eggplant salad and an effervescent fruit compote.
content: Speaking of summer weather, or weren’t we? I pronounce it “exceedingly hot and humid.” While that’s not true of everywhere, of course, I know many people who would emphatically answer yes when asked, “Hot enough for you?” And emphatically no when asked, “Are you going to cook?” Some won’t even turn on the oven or boil a pot of water from June to October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carly Olson
title: Driven by its first lady, Ukraine raises $5.4 million for off-road ambulances.
description: Olena Zelenska has recently become more visible in advocating for humanitarian causes.
content: As her husband, President Volodymyr Zelensky, calls on the nations of the world to supply Ukraine with weapons, Olena Zelenska is asking for ambulances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: After a First Date at Popeyes, Marriage Was on the Menu
description: Sharhea Wade was ready to forget about Stevenson Boyce, whom she met on Hinge, because he twice canceled their first date. But soon after a third (successful) attempt, she was ready to marry him.
content: The parking lot of Popeyes Louisiana Kitchen in the Roslindale neighborhood of Boston is not a particularly romantic spot for a first date. Nevertheless, when Stevenson Ricardo Boyce asked Sharhea Octavia Wade if she would meet him there one afternoon in May 2020, during the early days of the pandemic, she didn’t say no.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Emily Flitter
title: Carried Interest Is Back in the Headlines. Why It’s Not Going Away.
description: Changes demanded by Senator Kyrsten Sinema will preserve a tax loophole that Democrats have complained about for years.
content: For years, Democrats and even some Republicans such as former President Donald J. Trump have called for closing the so-called carried interest loophole that allows wealthy hedge fund managers and private equity executives to pay lower tax rates than entry-level employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marion Renault
title: ‘Something Is Wrong Here.’ More Than 100 Local Residents Had Brain Tumors, but What Was the Cause?
description: The complicated nature of cancer cluster investigations.
content: Al Lupiano, his wife and his sister all had brain tumors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Sinema Agrees to Climate and Tax Deal, Clearing the Way for Votes
description: The Arizona Democrat had been her party’s last remaining holdout on the package, now slated to move forward on Saturday and pass the Senate within days.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Kyrsten Sinema, Democrat of Arizona, announced on Thursday evening that she would support moving forward with her party’s climate, tax and health care package, clearing the way for a major piece of President Biden’s domestic agenda to move through the Senate in the coming days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Daniel Victor
title: Spain Limits Air-Conditioning to Save Energy
description: The country this week became the latest to announce restrictions, in part to promote energy efficiency but also to reduce consumption of Russian gas.
content: Public buildings in Spain will be cooled to no less than 27 degrees Celsius (81 Fahrenheit) in the summer, and heated to no more than 19 degrees Celsius (66 Fahrenheit) in the winter as part of a plan to save energy, the government said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: The Sandy Hook defamation cases have put Alex Jones’s finances under scrutiny.
description: The conspiracy theorist filed for bankruptcy for Infowars’ parent company, but lawyers for parents of the school shooting victims called it a ploy to shield him from paying damages.
content: Alex Jones’s attempts to shield his fortune from legal threats drew a warning this week from a Texas judge and new revelations about the finances of his misinformation operation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Gates
title: Bill Gates: We’re on the Verge of a Remarkable Moment for Congress and the Country
description: The Inflation Reduction Act may be the single-most important piece of climate legislation in American history.
content: Turn on the evening news and it immediately becomes clear that Americans are experiencing the effects of climate change. Extreme heat and drought are affecting tens of millions of people, as floods and wildfires ravage communities from Appalachia to California. In the coming days, Congress has the opportunity to face down the climate crisis while strengthening our country’s energy security, creating opportunities for businesses and improving the lives of Americans. We can’t afford to miss it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Margalit
title: Who Killed Tair Rada? Inside Israel’s True Crime Obsession
description: A TV documentary upended a murder case and captivated the nation. But its sensational theories might also be distorting justice.
content: There is little about the limestone courthouse in Nazareth, a predominantly Arab town in northern Israel, to suggest that it would be the setting of Israel’s most-talked-about trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Melissa Bank, Author Whose ‘Girls’ Guide’ Was a Phenomenon, Dies at 61
description: Her story collection “The Girls’ Guide to Hunting and Fishing,” her first book, has been translated into dozens of languages and has sold more than 1.5 million copies.
content: Melissa Bank, a witty, acerbic writer whose first book, “The Girls’ Guide to Hunting and Fishing,” became a global publishing phenomenon in 1999, died on Tuesday at her home in East Hampton, N.Y. She was 61.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Thomas Fuller
title: In Chinatown and the Bay Area, Residents React to Pelosi’s Trip
description: Chinese and Taiwanese Americans offer varying thoughts on the House speaker’s visit.
content: Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan this week drew concern from U.S. allies in Asia, support from Republican senators and sharp criticism from China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Facing Energy Crisis, Germans, Warily, Give Nuclear a Second Look
description: For three decades, nuclear power was one of Germany’s most divisive debates. But with Russia cutting gas, Germans are revisiting their political energy taboos.
content: LANDSHUT, Germany — When Angela Merkel pulled the plug on nuclear power after the Fukushima meltdown, she set Germany on a course to become the only leading industrial nation to abandon atomic energy in the world. The economic engine of Europe planned instead to fuel itself through a transition to renewable energies with cheap Russian gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Damien Cave
title: U.S. Seeks to Reassure Asian Allies as China’s Military Grows Bolder
description: The Biden administration says its commitment to the region has only deepened, but critics say the tensions over Taiwan show that Washington needs stronger military and economic strategies.
content: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Just a few hours after five Chinese missiles blasted into Japanese waters near Taiwan, the foreign ministers of China and Japan found themselves uncomfortably close together, in the holding room for a gala dinner on Thursday night at a meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: ‘Most Severe’ Drought Grips France as Extreme Heat Persists in Europe
description: A lack of rain and a string of heat waves have caused devastating wildfires and left farmland parched in the country and much of the continent.
content: PARIS — France declared Friday that it was in the grip of its “most severe” drought, one that has also desiccated large areas of Europe this summer, causing wildfires and imperiling crops as temperature records shatter across the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: Alex Eaton-Salners lays down some cool puns for a hot summer.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s variety constructor, Alex Eaton-Salners, is a prolific Times crossword contributor who makes a lot of Thursday grids, which demand the type of imagination that must create laundry lists of interesting homophones, word reversals, anagrams and double definitions.  Those that don’t become part of a theme eventually coalesce into a puns-and-anagrams puzzle like this one, I guess, and we are the lucky beneficiaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: Joining a Theater Club Set the Stage for Romance
description: After meeting as freshman members of a theater club at the University of Alabama, Allison Lyn Mollenkamp and William James McCrary soon took on important roles in each other’s lives.
content: As freshmen at the University of Alabama, Allison Lyn Mollenkamp and William James McCrary were among a group of seven students that staged a production of “Foreplay Or: The Art of the Fugue,” a short play from the anthology “All in the Timing,” written by David Ives.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: An Imperfect Decade
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 5, 2022
content: “A perfect game is not a goal, it’s something that just happens in the moment. It’s such an incredible thing, the stars have to align.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Jurors in the Alex Jones Trial Get to Pose Questions to Witnesses — and They Are Revealing.
description: After Mr. Jones cast jurors on his broadcast as ignorant “blue-collar” people handpicked by his political enemies, they asked for his definition of “blue collar.”
content: Judge Maya Guerra Gamble of the Travis County District Court employed an unusual practice during the Alex Jones defamation trial: She allowed the jury to ask written questions of all witnesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: A Town in Washington State Is Evacuated as a Wildfire Burns Six Houses
description: The fire also destroyed eight other structures as it burned about 2,500 acres in and around the town of Lind, Wash., on Thursday, the authorities said.
content: A small town in Washington state was temporarily evacuated on Thursday after a fast-moving wildfire destroyed at least six homes, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cristal Duhaime, Stephanie Joyce, Larissa Anderson, Lisa Tobin, Kaari Pitkin, Anita Badejo, Isaac Jones, Carole Sabouraud, Chris Wood and Corey Schreppel
title: Vacationing in the Time of Covid
description: The story of one man’s determination to resume traveling — despite the particular risks to his health.
content: Charles Falls Jr., known as Chillie, loves to take cruises. But Covid, as it has done for so many, left him marooned at home in Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Why Monkeypox Vaccine Shortage May Threaten the Immunocompromised
description: People with H.I.V. and other immune-system problems may need the full two-dose regimen, researchers say. But the shots, particularly second doses, are hard to come by.
content: The shortfall of monkeypox vaccine doses in the United States, expected to last for months, is raising urgent questions about how well and for how long a single shot may protect against the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: How Republicans Are ‘Weaponizing’ Public Office Against Climate Action
description: A Times investigation revealed a coordinated effort by state treasurers to use government muscle and public funds to punish companies trying to reduce greenhouse gases.
content: Nearly two dozen Republican state treasurers around the country are working to thwart climate action on state and federal levels, fighting regulations that would make clear the economic risks posed by a warming world, lobbying against climate-minded nominees to key federal posts and using the tax dollars they control to punish companies that want to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: A Road Trip to Sample America’s Many, Many Music Festivals
description: With a minivan and a three small children in tow, a critic spent 12 days discovering classical music offerings among the Rocky Mountains.
content: Four classical music festivals. Three children. Two exhausted parents, with a brave grandfather in tow. One bedraggled minivan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Lubow
title: Questioning the Place of Black Art in a White Man’s Collection
description: Isaac Julien’s installation at the Barnes Foundation highlights the museum’s African sculptures even as it questions the ethics of their acquisition.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Dazzled by the iconic Cézanne, Matisse and Seurat paintings, most visitors to the Barnes Foundation overlook the African sculptures. Yet to Albert C. Barnes, who founded the collection, they were central. He started acquiring African sculpture in 1922, the year he set up the foundation, because it had inspired Picasso, Modigliani and many other artists in France he supported. “When the Foundation opens, Negro art will have a place among the great art manifestations of all times,” he wrote to his Parisian dealer in 1923.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: In ‘A League of Their Own,’ Abbi Jacobson Makes the Team
description: Jacobson cocreated and stars in this new Amazon series, which expands the story told in Penny Marshall’s 1992 film.
content: Abbi Jacobson really can play baseball, she insisted. Just not when the cameras are rolling. “I fully get the yips when someone is watching me,” she told me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Hanlon
title: But I Wanted a Puppy!
description: Older siblings react to the arrival of new babies — in a picture book, a chapter book, an early reader and a middle grade novel.
content: I recently asked my sister about my birth; she was 4, my brother was 2. She mentioned that Mom bought them gifts and declared they were from me, the newborn. “What were the gifts?” I asked her. “The milk bottles, Abby!” she shouted into the phone as if this should be self-evident. I gasped. “The milk bottles?” No toy had more versatility or longevity in our universe. She described her conviction that I, like a “good houseguest,” had entered her life bearing those six plastic Fisher-Price bottles with multicolored tops, nestled in a yellow carrying case. “But when did you question this?” I asked her. “I never did,” she said unequivocally. How nice to begin the longest relationship many of us are fortunate enough to have on the right foot!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Putin and Erdogan find more room to cooperate at a meeting in Sochi, Russia.
description: The Turkish and Russian leaders sat face-to-face for the second time in less than three weeks, solidifying Turkey’s role as a bridge to the West and a mediator between Russia and Ukraine.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his Turkish counterpart, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, held marathon talks on a range of complementary and clashing interests on Friday, pledging to strengthen economic ties at a time when Turkey is emerging as a main trade bridge for Moscow to the rest of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Katie Glueck
title: Republicans Begin Adjusting to a Fierce Abortion Backlash
description: After Kansans voted to preserve abortion access, Republicans who once said the economy reigns supreme are acknowledging the issue will be a centerpiece in the fall campaigns.
content: Republican candidates, facing a stark reality check from Kansas voters, are softening their once-uncompromising stands against abortion as they move toward the general election, recognizing that strict bans are unpopular and that the issue may be a major driver in the fall campaigns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and David F. Gallagher
title: A Tax Loophole’s Powerful Defender
description: Senator Kyrsten Sinema had one main request before she would support a key spending bill: Preserve a tax loophole that mainly benefits people in private equity.
content: Sinema is in. But a plan to close a big tax loophole is out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Coal vs. Wall Street
description: Republican state officials have found a new way to push back against “woke capitalism”— by punishing companies that distance themselves from fossil fuels.
content: Climate change isn’t a partisan issue in many countries. Both right-leaning and left-leaning parties favor policies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, even if they fight over the specifics of those policies. This consensus allowed the European Union to cut emissions sharply over the past few decades, as the threat of global warming became clearer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Coco Gauff vs. Naomi Osaka Could Be a (Friendly) Rivalry in the Making
description: Gauff, 18, and Osaka, 24, played a cracker of a match Thursday night in San Jose, Calif., as they prepared for the U.S. Open.
content: Maybe, some years in the future, if Coco Gauff goes on to fulfill the destiny that some have predicted for her, her win over Naomi Osaka, 6-4, 6-4, on Thursday night will serve as a torch-passing moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong, Neil MacFarquhar and Natalie Kitroeff
title: U.S. and Russia Ready to Negotiate Griner’s Release
description: The countries’ top envoys made separate announcements after a meeting where they sat close together — without talking.
content: On the day after Brittney Griner was sentenced to a Russian penal colony, the top diplomats of the United States and Russia said on Friday that their governments were ready to negotiate for the release of both the American basketball star and Paul N. Whelan, who is also imprisoned by Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: South Korea Is Scouting Out the Moon, With More Missions to Come
description: The Danuri spacecraft, which launched on Thursday, aims to provide a lunar scientific bounty while preparing the country’s small space program for future exploration.
content: South Korea set off for the moon on Thursday. But it doesn’t want to stop there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Mike Isaac
title: The Humbling of Coinbase
description: In just over a year, the United States’ largest cryptocurrency exchange went from a triumphant public offering to a “crypto winter” of cost cutting and layoffs.
content: Brian Armstrong, the chief executive of the largest cryptocurrency exchange in the United States, traveled across the world to make an announcement in early April: Coinbase was bringing crypto to India.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yuval Levin
title: It Was a Mistake to Let Kids Onto Social Media Sites. Here’s What to Do Now.
description: Changing a law to raise the age requirement for social media use could empower parents.
content: Parenthood has always been fraught with worry and guilt, but parents in the age of social media have increasingly confronted a distinctly acute kind of powerlessness. Their kids are unwitting subjects in a remarkable experiment in human social forms, building habits and relationships in an unruly environment designed mostly to maximize intense engagement in the service of advertisers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trevor Noah Rips Russia for Brittney Griner Sentence
description: “We all know Russia doesn’t care about what Brittney Griner did,” Noah said, calling Russia “the same country that’s breaking every human rights law on the planet.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Man Who Threatened to Kill Fauci Is Sentenced to 3 Years in Prison
description: Thomas Patrick Connally Jr., 56, pleaded guilty in May to making threats against a federal official and also admitted to sending threatening messages to other health officials, federal prosecutors said.
content: A federal judge on Thursday sentenced a West Virginia man to more than three years in prison for sending threatening emails to Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, including one in which he said the immunologist and his family would be beaten to death and set on fire, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Gloomy about the economy and inflation, Americans remain upbeat about jobs.
description: In a survey, most say that it is a good time to find work and that the labor market favors employees. They see little change ahead for at least six months.
content: Americans are worried about inflation, pessimistic about the economy overall and upset about the way their leaders are handling it. But they still feel pretty good about the job market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: For Alex Jones, a Moment of Truth in a Flood of Lies
description: Nothing about his apology merits forgiveness.
content: In America’s clash between information and disinformation, the facts just won a rare round: Alex Jones has conceded that the mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., on Dec. 14, 2012, which he had repeatedly told millions of readers of his alt-right website Infowars was “a hoax” perpetrated by “actors,” was, in point of fact, “100 percent real.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Ronald J. Sider, Who Urged Evangelicals to Social Action, Dies at 82
description: He often bucked the rightward trend among some Christians, and in a popular 1977 book he argued that faith meant more than just personal salvation.
content: Ronald J. Sider, an evangelical Christian author and speaker who, in an era when evangelicals increasingly aligned themselves with the political right, argued that Christ called the faithful to attend to social justice issues like racism and poverty, died on July 27 at his home in Lansdale, Pa., near Philadelphia. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Ackerberg
title: Mitch Epstein’s America: Funny, Nostalgic — and a Bit Lonely
description: Between the 1970s and 1990s, the photographer captured a nation at leisure.
content: In 2005, the American photographer Mitch Epstein published a book of photographs of American people, from New York to Los Angeles, Dallas to Gary, Ind., between the early 1970s and the early 1990s. A new, updated edition of RECREATION (Steidl, $85), edited by Susan Bell and Ryan Spencer, includes 34 previously unseen images, creating an expanded portrait of a nation at various forms of leisure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Perlez, Alexandra Stevenson, John Liu and Michael Crowley
title: China Sends Ships and Planes Toward Taiwan, Defying Rising Criticism
description: Beijing also halted talks with the United States on the military, climate change and other issues, sending ties between the two powers into a deeper chill.
content: China sent a force of warships and aircraft into waters and airspace near Taiwan on Friday, defying international criticism of its military exercises and demonstrating the country’s growing appetite for confrontation over the island that it claims as its territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: Amber Midthunder Has a New Action Hero for You
description: She is gaining a reputation for such roles with films like “The Ice Road” and her latest, “Prey.” She’s the rare Native American actress to star in the genre.
content: It was the day a grand showdown fight in “Prey” was to be shot, and Amber Midthunder felt awful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joyce Cohen
title: A Gothic Rock Cottage Fit for a Bat Out of Hell
description: Jim Steinman spent years transforming his Connecticut house into a kind of rock ‘n’ roll museum. Now his friends are trying to sell it — with his belongings intact.
content: Jim Steinman, who died last year at 73, left behind one of the most distinctive catalogs of music in history, filled with chart-topping hits written for the likes of Meat Loaf, Bonnie Tyler and Celine Dion. With songs ranging from the restless (“All Revved Up With No Place To Go”) to the wrenching (“For Crying Out Loud”), Mr. Steinman spent decades establishing himself as a sophisticated songwriter with the spirit of a teenager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: Pregnant Men Were a Movie Punchline. Now They’re Horror Villains.
description: The idea of the pregnant man has long been mined for Hollywood comedy. This summer, he becomes a menace.
content: When I was four months pregnant, just as my midsection had grown vast enough to convert my pregnancy into a public event, I escaped to the movies. I saw “Men,” Alex Garland’s May horror film about the young widow Harper (Jessie Buckley), who sets out on a restorative countryside getaway only to be terrorized by a village full of unsavory male archetypes — pervy vicar, passive-aggressive nice guy, condescending cop — all played by Rory Kinnear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The Home Runs Kept Coming, but It Wasn’t Enough
description: Los Angeles went deep seven times on Thursday — with Shohei Ohtani hitting two — but managed to lose anyway. For better or worse, that is the Angels’ way.
content: For a team that boasts Mike Trout and Shohei Ohtani, the Los Angeles Angels sure lose a lot of games: 61 so far, with only 44 wins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Chaon
title: Heard the One About the Hole That Swallowed Part of Chicago?
description: “Mount Chicago,” Adam Levin’s new novel, is an absurdist epic for an age of disasters.
content: Adam Levin’s expansive new novel begins with a high-concept catastrophe. One day in November 2021, a crater opens up in Chicago and swallows a swath of Michigan Avenue, along with many thousands of people. It’s a timely setup in this age of disasters beyond parody, and Levin homes in hilariously on the lame official response. The mayor and his P.R. people call the inexplicable disaster a “terrestrial anomaly,” since the euphemism seismic event has “earthquakian overtones” and the term sinkhole is too reminiscent of Florida: Sinkholes “made you think of swamps and they made you think of armpits. Swampy armpits. Meth, opossums, thrush. … People in mourning did not need that.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Why College Students May Need Renter’s Insurance
description: The insurance can help pay for property damaged in a fire or stolen. And replacing clothes, furniture and electronic gadgets adds up.
content: College students who are already shopping for laptops, textbooks and other campus gear may want to add something else to their list: renter’s insurance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilaria Parogni
title: Overlooked No More: Alda Merini, Poet Who Wrote of Life’s Joys and Struggles
description: Countless fans have been intrigued by her verses carrying erotic and sacred imagery, and by her life, from her childhood in Milan to her time spent in asylums.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Glass
title: Please, God, Help Me Stop Missing Her
description: As an ultra-Orthodox Jew, I tried to “pray my gay away.” It didn’t work.
content: I was scrolling through psychotherapy memes on Instagram a few years ago when Hannah popped up in my friend requests. We each had new last names and new looks. I had decided that since I had to wear wigs anyway (as an ultra-Orthodox Jew), they may as well be blond instead of my natural dull brown. She wore a mixture of wigs and other creative head coverings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: After Floods in Kentucky, a Reporter Lets Residents Talk
description: Rick Rojas, a national correspondent for The Times, spent three days this week in southeastern Kentucky, where flash floods devastated communities that were already stressed.
content: Rick Rojas, a New York Times national correspondent based in Nashville, was working out of the Times newsroom in Manhattan when the flooding started in southeastern Kentucky last week. Flash floods were barreling down the region's steep terrain, and endangering lives. The disaster has now killed at least 37 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: ‘Easter Sunday’ Review: A Feel-Good Filipino Family Comedy
description: Jo Koy stars as a struggling comedian who is balancing his acting career with the demands of his son and mother.
content: “Easter Sunday” has all the makings of a rollicking family comedy: The protagonist is a struggling actor and comedian with wacky relatives and a rocky relationship with his son. The film features mostly Filipino actors, with wonderful, culturally specific jokes and a cast of characters that fit into stereotypical, but no less true, immigrant archetypes. Not only Filipino viewers will see their families represented here; much of it rang true to this Dominican reviewer, as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: A U.S. diplomat warns African countries against buying anything from Russia except grain and fertilizer.
description: “We caution countries not to break those sanctions,” the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Linda Thomas-Greenfield said, warning of that they stood the chance “of having actions taken against them.”
content: Ahead of a trip to Uganda and Ghana this week, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Linda Thomas-Greenfield, said in an interview that it would be a “listening tour” and that she wanted to find solutions, not assign blame, over a food insecurity crisis intensifying on the African continent since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley
title: Good News on Jobs May Mean Bad News Later as Hiring Spree Defies Fed
description: Employers hired rapidly and paid more in July, suggesting the Federal Reserve may have to remain aggressive in its effort to cool the economy.
content: America’s job market is remarkably strong, a report on Friday made clear, with unemployment at the lowest rate in half a century, wages rising fast and companies hiring at a breakneck pace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Margolick
title: A Mother on a Mission: World-Class Music for Everyone
description: Community Concerts aimed for “a Carnegie Hall in every town.” Its adherents, including the author’s mother, were devoted to the cause. For decades, the experiment worked.
content: After Don Shirley performed with his trio before an appreciative audience in the Putnam High School auditorium in November 1965, he did not go back to his lonely motel room and hit the Cutty Sark, the way he did in the movie “Green Book” — at least not right away. Thanks largely to my mother, he came to our house first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: What Was Revealed About Alex Jones’s Net Worth and More in His Trial
description: The closely watched proceedings delved into Mr. Jones’s finances and included text messages that his lawyers had accidentally sent to attorneys for the families of Sandy Hook victims.
content: The trial this week for damages that the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones must pay to the parents of a child killed in the 2012 mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School has revealed interesting details about Mr. Jones and his Infowars media company, which he used to spread lies about the shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKenna Oxenden
title: Lightning Strike Near White House Kills 3
description: A couple from Wisconsin and a 29-year-old man died after lightning struck Lafayette Square in Washington, officials said. One other person was in critical condition.
content: Three people have died after a lightning strike in a park just north of the White House on Thursday night, officials said. A fourth person was in critical condition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Carly Rae Jepsen’s Brand-New Boy Problems, and 7 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by DJ Khaled featuring Drake and Lil Baby, Panda Bear & Sonic Boom, the 1975 and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: She’s the Secret Weapon in a Film About the Thai Cave Rescue
description: For Ron Howard’s retelling of the 2018 ordeal, Pattrakorn Tungsupakul not only played the mother of a stranded boy, she also made key script contributions.
content: When Ron Howard set out to retell the story of the dramatic 2018 rescue of a young soccer team from a flooded cave in northern Thailand, he knew he would have to grapple with underwater photography, hordes of extras and a handful of surly protagonists in the form of the British divers who successfully saved the boys through extraordinary methods. But he also knew that, as an American director tackling a specifically Thai story, authenticity would be crucial — and that any deviation from verisimilitude would come at his peril.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Kathryn Bond Stockton
description: A conversation with the queer theorist
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Kathryn Bond Stockton. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: What I’m reading
description: The seismic shifts of the 1960s are still reverberating in the Democratic Party.
content: I’ve written a lot lately about America in the 1960s  and the way that the backlash to civil rights paved the way for the modern Republican Party’s hard-line positions on gun control and abortion bans. But I haven’t spent as much time looking at what happened within the Democratic Party that enabled that seismic shift to happen. So this week I’ve been remedying that with a giant stack of vacation reading:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Emily Flitter and Kate Kelly
title: The Carried Interest Loophole Survives Another Political Battle
description: The latest effort to narrow the preferential tax treatment used by private equity executives failed after Senator Kyrsten Sinema objected.
content: WASHINGTON — Once again, carried interest carried the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Fawcett
title: Several Northeast Cities Set New Record Temperatures Amid Heat Wave
description: The region’s heat wave was expected to ease somewhat on Friday, with anticipated highs in the mid-90s.
content: Several cities across the Northeast reported record-breaking temperatures on Thursday, as a heat wave that has covered much of the United States this week peaked in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch Daniel Kaluuya Face a U.F.O. in ‘Nope’
description: The writer-director Jordan Peele narrates a harrowing sequence from his film.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Raja Kumari Brings West Coast Rap to India
description: After writing songs for Gwen Stefani and Iggy Azalea, she is now producing singles under her own label, Godmother Records.
content: Name: Raja Kumari
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: How floods become human catastrophes
description: Parts of the South and Midwest are cleaning up from deadly flooding. We explain the factors that sharply increased the risks.
content: The greatest hazard of the climate-changed era is often just the hard fact of being poor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: The jobs report suggests President Biden is right about a recession.
description: But the unexpectedly strong employment growth reported for July also appeared to contradict forecasts that the economy was cooling off.
content: The strong jobs report was welcome news for President Biden, who has insisted in recent weeks that the United States is not in recession, even though it has suffered two consecutive quarters of economic contraction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: They Got to the Premier League. Staying? That’s the Hard Part.
description: Fulham has made a habit of bouncing in and out of the world’s richest soccer competition in recent years. Is there a business model in being almost good enough?
content: LONDON — The thing about Aleksandar Mitrovic is that he is not just a striker, barrel-chested and shaven-headed and keen-eyed. He is not simply a Serbian international, a fairly constant presence for his country for the better part of a decade. Nor is he merely something of a national hero, scorer of the goal that sent his country to the World Cup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Rebecca Robbins
title: Democrats’ Long-Sought Plan for Lowering Drug Costs Is at Hand
description: Empowering Medicare to negotiate prices directly with drug makers has been a Democratic goal for 30 years, one the pharmaceutical industry has fought ferociously.
content: WASHINGTON — For decades, as prescription drug costs have soared, Democrats have battled with the pharmaceutical industry in pursuit of an elusive goal: legislation that could drive down prices by allowing Medicare to negotiate directly with drug makers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Dee Hock, Credit Card Visionary, Is Dead at 93
description: As chief executive of Visa, he transformed a struggling company into a global powerhouse and the world’s leading credit card network.
content: Dee Hock, a banker with a junior college degree who shaped the Visa credit card into a global financial behemoth, died on July 16 at his home in Olympia, Wash. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Roberts
title: The Mysterious Dance of the Cricket Embryos
description: A team of biologists and mathematicians studied hours of video to learn how insects take shape in the egg. The secret is geometry.
content: In June, 100 fruit fly scientists gathered on the Greek island of Crete for their biennial meeting. Among them was Cassandra Extavour, a Canadian geneticist at Harvard University. Her lab works with fruit flies to study evolution and development — “evo devo.” Most often, such scientists choose as their “model organism” the species Drosophila melanogaster — a winged workhorse that has served as an insect collaborator on at least a few Nobel Prizes in physiology and medicine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William MacAskill
title: The Case for Longtermism
description: We are living through an extraordinary and precarious chapter in humanity’s story.
content: Imagine living the life of every human being who has ever existed — in order of birth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran Targets Its Baha’i Community With Arrests and Home Demolitions
description: Representatives of the religious minority said that the crackdown was the latest chapter in a long history of persecution. The authorities accused those detained of being spies with links to Israel.
content: Iran has begun a sweeping crackdown on its Baha’i community, a long-persecuted religious minority, arresting dozens of people and destroying property belonging to members of the group, according to accounts this week from the government, residents and rights groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: New York May Face ‘Tip of the Iceberg’ With Polio, Health Chief Says
description: With increased urgency, state officials called for residents to get vaccinated against the disease after it was found in a second county’s wastewater.
content: New York State health officials on Thursday intensified their push for people who have not been immunized against polio to get vaccinated “right away,” saying the one confirmed case of the disease found in the state may be “the tip of the iceberg” of a much wider threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo and Caroline Tompkins
title: 3 Days. 68 Kids. Snapshots of Summer on Coney Island.
description: The New York Times for Kids visited the quirky but classic destination.
content: What would summer be without a little heat? A little adventure? A little mischief? Last month, The New York Times for Kids visited Coney Island to get all three. Along the beach, in the maze of rides at Luna Park and on the sandy boardwalk, we found and spoke to more than 50 kids to find out what they love most about this quirky but classic New York destination. For some kids, it was the roller coasters. For others, it was just being with their friends when school’s out. Yet one thing seemed to be true among the kids we met: There’s no better place to stay cool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Fourteen Years Later, They Finally, Fortunately, Wed
description: Brandi Broxson and Francisco Garcia, who dated for more than a decade, say loved ones use the term “finally” when referring to their marriage. The couple has chosen a different word: “fortunately.”
content: When Francisco Omar Garcia met Brandi Kaye Broxson at a now-closed bar in Orlando, Fla., in April 2008, it was his clothes that at first did the talking. Before agreeing to dance with Mr. Garcia, Ms. Broxson had taken notice of his white T-shirt, which read “Are you my type?” across the chest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: The Meaning of Falling Inflation
description: Don’t get carried away, but do accept the good news.
content: Inflation is coming down — fast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Stephanie Lai
title: Clock Running Out on Antitrust Bill Targeting Big Tech
description: A sweeping bill that would enact the strongest restrictions on Big Tech companies in the United States has been stalled in the Senate.
content: WASHINGTON — Critics of the country’s largest tech companies branded the last few months “Hot Antitrust Summer” because they hoped that Congress would vote on new regulations for Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Griner’s Sentence Renews Pressure on President Biden
description: The basketball star’s supporters are pressing for action. But critics of any possible deal are already fuming.
content: WASHINGTON — Immediately after a Moscow judge handed down Brittney Griner’s nine-year prison sentence on Thursday, calls grew louder for President Biden to find a way to bring her home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Kari Lake, Backed by Trump, Wins Arizona’s G.O.P. Governor Primary
description: Running a campaign heavily focused on false claims of a stolen 2020 election, Ms. Lake beat a rival supported by the state’s G.O.P. establishment and its departing governor, Doug Ducey.
content: Kari Lake, who in the span of two years transformed herself from a veteran local television news anchor into a tribune of the far-right political movement, won Arizona’s Republican primary for governor, according to The Associated Press.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: ‘This Broke Me’: Parkland Trial Reveals Depths of Families’ Sorrow
description: The rare trial of a gunman in a mass shooting has underscored how massacres shatter families and communities over time.
content: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Peter Wang’s mother has four tattoos memorializing her 15-year-old son, one inked on Feb. 14 each year since he was killed. Carmen Schentrup’s parents find sleep elusive. Nicholas Dworet’s mother hesitates every time someone asks her, “How many kids do you have?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Okrent
title: Broadway Baby: The Astonishing Autobiography of Mary Rodgers
description: The daughter of Richard Rodgers, confidante of Stephen Sondheim and composer of “Once Upon a Mattress” holds nothing back in “Shy.”
content: Let’s start with a full disclosure: I’m a sucker for Broadway — one of those theater fans who will see five different productions of the same show, who genuflect before cast albums from the ’50s, who inhale theater gossip as if it really mattered. I’m also a sucker for books about Broadway, books as different from one another as Moss Hart’s “Act One,” William Goldman’s “The Season” and Jack Viertel’s “The Secret Life of the American Musical.” But I’ve never read one more entertaining (and more revealing) than Mary Rodgers’s “Shy.” Her voice careens between intimate, sardonic, confessional, comic. The book is pure pleasure — except when it’s jaw-droppingly shocking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley and Raja Abdulrahim
title: Israel Hits Gaza, Prompting Rocket Barrage and Ending Relative Calm
description: In by far the biggest escalation of violence in Gaza since the end of a war in May 2021, Israeli airstrikes killed a militant leader and at least nine others, according to Palestinian officials.
content: TEL AVIV — Israeli airstrikes hit several targets in the Gaza Strip on Friday, prompting Palestinian militants to return fire with scores of rockets, in the deadliest escalation of violence in the territory since an 11-day war last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Matthew Cullen
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Brittney Griner is sentenced in Russia.
content: A Russian court sentenced Brittney Griner, the W.N.B.A. star who has been detained in Moscow since February, to nine years in a penal colony after finding her guilty of bringing illegal drugs into Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: A New National Health Emergency
description: And the new rules of travel.
content: We’re taking a detour from our regular Covid coverage to keep you up to speed on the monkeypox outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: A.I. Is Not Sentient. Why Do People Say It Is?
description: Robots can’t think or feel, despite what the researchers who build them want to believe.
content: As the sun set over Maury Island, just south of Seattle, Ben Goertzel and his jazz fusion band had one of those moments that all bands hope for — keyboard, guitar, saxophone and lead singer coming together as if they were one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Taylor
title: For the Art of Love and the Love of Art
description: In “Bonsai,” Alejandro Zambra tells the story of two young lovers whose lives, relationship and heartbreak intertwine with art and literature.
content: Alejandro Zambra’s “Bonsai” (translated from the Spanish by Megan McDowell) begins with an ending: “In the end she dies and he is alone, although really he had been alone for some years before her death.” What follows is a truly sublime novella as we watch Julio (the aforementioned “he”) and Emilia (the aforementioned “her”) encounter each other, fall in love, then fall out of touch, until Julio discovers in the novella’s last, beautiful pages that Emilia is dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Mary Ellin Barrett, Daughter and Defender of Irving Berlin, Dies at 95
description: When the great American songwriter’s character came under attack after his death, Ms. Barrett sought to correct the record with a candid but tender memoir.
content: The songwriter Irving Berlin defined a very American style of sunniness. “Anything You Can Do (I Can Do Better)” delighted in competition. “Puttin’ On the Ritz” made social mobility silly. “White Christmas” exalted innocence. With “God Bless America,” Berlin, an immigrant from Russia, wrote the unofficial second national anthem of his adopted home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Kylie Minogue Mixes Her Signature Cocktail
description: The pop star returned to the Carlyle Hotel after celebrating her wine collection there.
content: Kylie Minogue’s early experiences of alcohol were not especially glamorous — canned drinks with teenage friends, boxed wine at family barbecues. But Ms. Minogue, 54, the only female artist to have topped music charts in five consecutive decades, has refined her relationship to liquor since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: With Surge in July, U.S. Recovers the Jobs Lost in the Pandemic
description: The increase of 528,000 outstripped expectations, and the gains were spread widely across industries. The jobless rate fell to 3.5 percent.
content: U.S. job growth accelerated in July across nearly all industries, restoring nationwide employment to its prepandemic level, despite widespread expectations of a slowdown as the Federal Reserve raises interest rates to fight inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Near Castle Ruins, a Wedding with a Dash of ‘Game of Thrones’
description: After matching on Bumble, Kristen Sanders, a police officer, and April Hill, a makeup artist, began a courtship that ended with a marriage ceremony overlooking Dunluce Castle, in Northern Ireland.
content: Kristen Sanders thought her chances of a relationship with April Hill were pretty slim when she spotted Ms. Hill’s profile on the dating app Bumble in January 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yu-Jie Chen
title: I’m Taiwanese, and I Want to Thank Nancy Pelosi
description: Taiwan needs more leaders to stand with us against China.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — As a Taiwanese, I’m sometimes asked what it’s like living in “the most dangerous place on earth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Progressives Embrace Climate and Tax Deal, Despite Disappointments
description: Liberal Democrats who once demanded a far more ambitious plan appear ready to support a climate, health and tax package that could be their party’s last chance to enact some of its agenda.
content: WASHINGTON — With enactment of a major piece of Democrats’ domestic agenda in sight within days, progressives in Congress are rallying, grudgingly but decisively, around a climate, health and tax package that is a shadow of the ambitious cradle-to-grave social policy overhaul they once demanded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristie Koerbel
title: 20 Years at 30,000 Feet: A Flight Attendant Answers Readers’ Questions
description: Does the cabin crew ever get scared in the air? Is there a secret flight attendant code? How do I survive a flight with my toddler? An industry insider answers.
content: As a flight attendant who has been on the job for 20 years, it’s easy to take my travel insights for granted — the little tips and tricks that make the journey smoother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Hair-Highlighting Technique
description: Erik Agard and Brooke Husic open our solving weekend.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Let’s say that you are trying to improve your solving, and you have managed to push yourself to the point where themed puzzles are starting to become a little ho-hum. Sure, Thursday themes are fun, but do you have the moxie to make the leap into Friday themeless crossword fare, which happens to be the second-hardest puzzle of the week?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: The Republican National Convention Will Be Held in Milwaukee in 2024
description: In choosing Milwaukee, Republicans picked an overwhelmingly Democratic city in America’s pre-eminent battleground state.
content: The Republican National Committee will hold its 2024 convention in Milwaukee, Ronna McDaniel, the party’s chairwoman, announced Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Opponents of Outdoor Dining Renew Fight Against Sheds
description: Mayor Eric Adams is a big supporter of outdoor dining, but those who dislike the program are trying to kill it in court.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll see why a coalition from across the city is challenging streeteries. We’ll also look at a program that makes art accessible and is settling into a new home in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the staff of The Morning
title: What Questions Do You Have About Spelling Bee?
description: The Bee’s editor will answer them.
content: Calling all word game fans: Do you have questions about Spelling Bee? The Bee’s editor, Sam Ezersky, will answer some in a future edition of The Morning newsletter. Please submit them by Wednesday, Aug. 10. And no questions about individual words, please.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: 3 Downpours in 8 Days: How Extreme Rain Soaked the Midwest
description: Back-to-back deluges swamped Kentucky, Missouri and Illinois. These types of storms are expected to be more frequent and more intense as the planet warms, climate experts say.
content: Three separate downpours across three states over a span of eight days this summer swept away homes, destroyed crops and left at least 39 people dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: The Composer Huang Ruo on Illusion and Betrayal in ‘M. Butterfly’
description: Huang, who wrote the music for the operatic adaptation of David Henry Hwang’s play, says its exploration of race, gender and power still resonates today.
content: The question from the Chinese-born composer Huang Ruo came out of the blue: Would David Henry Hwang, the American playwright, consider adapting his Broadway hit “M. Butterfly” for the opera stage?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Fetterman Plans His Return to Campaign Trail in Pennsylvania Senate Race
description: Mr. Fetterman has been criticized by his opponent, Dr. Mehmet Oz, over his absence from in-person campaigning since he suffered a stroke in May.
content: Three months after John Fetterman, Pennsylvania’s Democratic Senate nominee, was sidelined by a stroke, he is planning to return to the campaign trail with a rally next Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Leon E. Rosenberg, Geneticist Who Wrote of His Depression, Dies at 89
description: After years of pioneering research into inherited disorders, mostly in children, he spoke openly about his struggle with mental illness.
content: Dr. Leon E. Rosenberg, who after spending decades as a pioneer in the field of medical genetics revealed that he had spent just as long struggling with manic depression, and who then urged doctors to be more open about their own mental health, died on July 22 at his home in Lawrenceville, N.J. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: Griner’s Tearful W.N.B.A. Teammates Play On After Her Conviction
description: Brittney Griner, the Phoenix Mercury star, was convicted on drug charges in Russia. Hours later, her teammates had a game. “Nobody even wanted to play today,” one said.
content: UNCASVILLE, Conn. — Phoenix Mercury Coach Vanessa Nygaard and her coaching staff stood in the empty Mohegan Sun arena on Thursday, puzzled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Lincoln Kitman
title: Jacques Pépin, in Search of Lost Cars and Cuisine
description: Have France’s distinctive food and automobiles slipped in their cultural cachet? The celebrity chef and serial owner of French cars has opinions on the matter.
content: While the French famously obsess about the dilution of their culture at home, it is not unfair to say that their great nation’s cultural sway appears to have dwindled in the larger world as well. To give two examples that touch me where I live, the primacy of French cuisine — once regarded as the world’s best — is finis. No longer is the cozy French bistro a staple of every American city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Man Charged With Killing Worker Over Duck Sauce Found Dead, Police Say
description: Authorities were checking on the man, Glenn Hirsch, after he failed to appear in court, according to his lawyer, who said his client appeared to have shot himself.
content: A man charged with murder last month in the killing of a Chinese food delivery worker amid a dispute over duck sauce was found dead on Friday after shooting himself in his Queens apartment, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Amazon to Buy Maker of the Roomba for $1.7 Billion

content: Hey, Alexa, tell Roomba to vacuum the bedroom.

title: Amid the Pandemic, the Rise of the Single-Issue Parent: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Gender Is Complicated for All of Us. Let’s Talk About It.
description: A distinguished professor helps me understand our complicated — and changing — culture around gender.
content: It’s hard to think of anything changing more quickly in our society right now than our understanding of gender. There’s an explosion of young people identifying as gender nonconforming in some way or another, and others are coming out as transgender or nonbinary throughout their lives, from childhood to old age. But this sea change has brought with it an enormous amount of confusion and resistance. As of July, lawmakers in 21 states had introduced bills that focus on restricting gender-affirming medical care for transgender youth, such as hormone blockers, and 29 states had introduced bills banning transgender youth from sports. But we also know that the degree of support young people receive — or don’t — when coming out can have profound consequences for their mental health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Dick Cheney excoriates Trump in an ad for his daughter Liz Cheney.
description: The one-minute ad landed with a bang on social media, but in Wyoming, it is highly unlikely to sway any significant number of voters in Ms. Cheney’s favor.
content: A new advertisement for Representative Liz Cheney’s re-election campaign features a leader of a bygone era in the Republican Party excoriating the leader of the current one.

title: Lessons From the ’80s, When Volcker Reigned and Rates Were High
description: When inflation was soaring 40 years ago and the economy slowed, short-term investing was perilous. But people with patience and long horizons came out fine.
content: The cost of living is sky-high, and the chair of the Federal Reserve says that battling it is his highest priority. Financial markets don’t know quite how to react.

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Sri Lankan Family Wins a Long Battle to Stay in Australia
description: Rights groups say they do not expect Australian immigration policy to change significantly with its new government, but the decision raised hopes for a more tolerant approach.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Four years ago, immigration officers arrived at dawn to rip a Sri Lankan family away from the life they had built in the tiny Australian town of Biloela.

author: By Lawrence Ulrich
title: After Losing Favor to Electric Cars, Plug-In Hybrids Gain Ground
description: There has been a surge in the sales of cars that can travel short distances on just electricity and have a gasoline engine for longer trips.
content: In late 2010, General Motors sought to seize the high ground from Toyota’s successful Prius hybrid with the Volt plug-in hybrid — a car that could drive short distances on only electricity and fire up a gasoline engine for long trips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Jurors award $45.2 million in punitive damages after lawyer for Sandy Hook parents asks them to ‘stop Alex Jones.’
description: The jury reached a decision on punitive damages after deliberating for about four hours, a day after awarding more than $4 million in compensatory damages to the parents of a child killed in the Sandy Hook shooting.

title: Corrections: Aug. 5, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Aug. 5, 2022.
content: An article on Thursday about Ukrainian refugees temporarily housed on a cruise ship leased by the Estonian government misstated the name of a group that issued a report on the refugees. It is the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, not the Organization for Economic Development and Cooperation.

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Grilled shrimp with chile, a classic Denver omelet and more recipes.
content: Good morning. I once had a fantastic wood-fired seafood pizza at the Seaside Café in Key West, Fla.: sweet and salty, luxurious with lobster meat, cream sauce, fontina and puréed garlic. The meat was plush, pillowy, perfectly cooked, and I wondered about that. If I put knuckles of cooked lobster on a pizza in a 1,000-degree wood oven, they’d turn into rubber chew toys.
source.name: The New York Times
